title: 111_hr4945
content: The Act is titled the "Census Oversight Efficiency and Management Reform Act of 2010" and outlines the authority and duties of the Director and Deputy Director of the Census. The "Census Oversight Efficiency and Management Reform Act of 2010" amends Section 21 of the title 13, United States Code, defining the roles of the Director and Deputy Director of the Census. The Director is appointed by the President with Senate approval and must have demonstrated ability. The Director of the Census must have management experience and statistical data expertise. They report directly to the Secretary of Commerce and have independence in their duties. No other government entity can require the Director to submit legislative recommendations or testimony for review. The Director of the Census has a 5-year term starting in 2012, with a limit of 2 terms. They have independence in their duties and are not required to submit recommendations or testimony to Congress for review. The Director of the Census can serve beyond their term until reappointed or until a successor is appointed, but not longer than 1 year after the term ends. The President can remove the Director from office, with reasons communicated to Congress. The Director is responsible for all powers and duties of the Bureau, with authority over personnel and activities. The Director of the Bureau may establish organizational units, advisory committees, and regulations to carry out necessary functions, with the ability to alter or discontinue units as needed. Members of advisory committees serve without compensation but are entitled to transportation expenses and per diem. The Director of the Bureau has the authority to assign duties, delegate tasks, and authorize redelegations to officers and employees as necessary. These actions must be published in the Federal Register before taking effect. The Director of the Bureau must provide budget information to specific committees before submitting the Department of Commerce budget to the Office of Management and Budget. All other budget requests to the Secretary must be available to the Committees on Appropriations. The Director of the Bureau can utilize personnel from other Federal agencies, including the Armed Forces, with consent. They can also accept voluntary services. Additionally, there is a Deputy Director of the Census appointed by the Director. The Deputy Director of the Bureau of the Census is a career reserved position appointed by the Director, responsible for performing designated functions. Transition rules outline the appointment of the initial Director and the interim role of the current director. The current director of the census will serve as the Director of the Bureau of the Census until the initial Director takes office, reporting directly to the Secretary of Commerce. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 1 of title 13, United States Code. The Secretary of Commerce, in consultation with the Director of the Census, will submit draft legislation to Congress by January 1, 2011, containing technical amendments to title 13, United States Code. This is to carry out the purposes of the Act. The Director of the Census will provide a plan to Congress within 180 days on implementing an Internet response option for the 2020 Census and American Community Survey. The plan will detail feasibility testing, stakeholder consultation, data collection, and data protection. Annual reports will also be submitted. The Director of the Census will submit annual reports to Congress on the next decennial census, starting with the 2020 census. The reports will include performance goals, measures, risks, and mitigation plans for significant census operations. The Director of the Census will submit annual reports to Congress on the next decennial census, starting with the 2020 census. The reports will include performance goals, measures, risks, and relevant mitigation plans, detailed milestone estimates, updated cost estimates, and descriptions of contracts over $50,000,000 for each significant decennial operation. The term 'significant decennial operation' includes programs related to address list development, data processing, hiring temporary employees, marketing, communications, and coverage measurement. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 1 of title 13, United States Code. The amendments made by this section regarding annual reports will apply to budget requests for fiscal years starting after September 30, 2010.
